tabData.tagHTML: Understanding Jain Symbols

Symbols are super important in religion! They show us big ideas in simple ways and give us a peek into a religion's culture and practices. Jain symbols help us understand the basic principles of Jainism.
Our Special Greeting

When Jains meet, we say 'Jai Jinendra'! It means, 'May the religion established by the Jina prevail in our hearts.' We say this because we see a Jina (a winner over inner enemies) in everyone. Every soul can become a Jina and overcome anger, ego, deceit, and greed. Jinas are also called Arihant and Tirthankar, and we think of them as our Jain gods.
Asking for Forgiveness

'Michchhämi Dukkadam' is how we ask for forgiveness. It means 'Forgive my faults.' We usually say this after a special annual forgiveness ritual called Samvatsari Pratikraman. But we can also use it every day for mistakes we make, big or small. It's best to ask for forgiveness as soon as you realize you've made a mistake!
Our Place of Worship

A Jinälay, also called a Deräsar or Mandir, is a Jain temple. It's a peaceful place where you can feel calm and serene. The statues of Tirthankars and the temple's quiet environment help us look inside ourselves and remember that God is within our own hearts. This helps us follow the right path to become pure and free ourselves from anger, ego, deceit, and greed.
The Sacred Om

The 'Om' symbol is found in many Indian religions. In Jainism, it's a very special sound and symbol. When an Arihant (a perfect being) gains complete knowledge, their body makes a spontaneous, melodious sound called Divya Dhvani (Divine Sound). Everyone, including humans, animals, and heavenly beings, can understand this sound in their own language!

The sound 'Aum' is a salutation to the five supreme beings in Jainism. It's made up of five sounds:
  • A: Represents Arihant (a living human who has conquered passions and realized their true self).
  • U: Represents Ashariri (Siddha, a liberated soul without a physical body).
  • M: Represents Ächärya (a spiritual leader of the Jain community).
  • U: Represents Upädhyäy (an ascetic teacher).
  • M: Represents Muni (Sädhus or Sädhvis who practice Jain principles).
Om is also a short form of the Namokär Mantra.
Hrim: The Mystical Symbol

The word 'Hrim' is a special seed mantra. It's like a mystical symbol for an invisible sound, endlessness, and the divine energy of the 24 Tirthankars. When you meditate on Hrim, you can feel the powerful energy of the Tirthankars.
Arhum: The Silent Sound

'Arhum' is another mantra that represents all the sounds in the Sanskrit alphabet, from the first vowel 'a' to the last consonant 'h'. When you meditate on Arhum, you focus on the silent sound of the universe.

tabData.title: Meanings of the Swastik
tabData.description: The Swastik is a very important and auspicious symbol in Jainism. It has many meanings!

cards.back: Heavenly being, human, hellish being, animal

tabData.title: Three Dots & Crescent
tabData.description: Above the Swastik, there are more symbols!

cards.back: Three Jewels of Jainism: Samyag Darshan (perfect perception), Samyag Jnän (knowledge), Samyak Chäritra (conduct)

tabData.tagHTML: The Forehead Mark

Many religions use special marks on the forehead called Tilaks. Jains use sandalwood paste mixed with saffron to make a Tilak between the eyebrows. This spot is a nerve center for decision-making and represents an 'inner sight' that sees beyond normal vision. It shows that Jains try to live by the teachings of the Tirthankars.

tabData.title: The Big Picture Symbol
tabData.description: This symbol combines many smaller symbols, each with a deep meaning. It was adopted during the 2500th Nirväna celebration of Bhagawän Mahävir.

items.content: The outline looks like the Universe (Lok). The bottom part is the seven hells (Näraki). The middle part is Earth and planets (Manushya-lok). The top part is the heavenly homes (Devlok) of celestial beings, and even higher is the home of the Siddhas (Siddha-kshetra). Jains believe this universe is eternal – it was never created and can't be destroyed.

The Swastik is explained in another section. The word in the center of the raised hand and wheel is 'Ahimsä', meaning non-violence. This part reminds us to stop and think before doing anything, to make sure our thoughts, words, and actions don't cause harm.

The wheel in the hand shows that if we are not careful, we will keep going through the cycle of birth and death. The words underneath, 'Parasparopagraho Jivänäm,' mean 'Living Beings (souls) Render Service to One Another.'

tabData.tagHTML: The Federation of JAINA Logo

The Federation of Jain Associations in North America (JAINA) uses its own symbol. In their logo, the Swastik from the main Jain symbol is replaced by the 'Aum' or 'Om' symbol. This is because in the Western world, the Swastik is not always seen as a good symbol.

tabData.title: The Ärati Ceremony
tabData.description: The Ärati is a beautiful ceremony performed with lamps.

items.content: The Ärati has 5 lamps with oil-soaked cotton wicks. The lamps are waved in a circle in front of a Tirthankar's idol at the end of a ritual and at night before the temple closes. The light symbolizes good overcoming bad, courage overcoming fear, and knowledge overcoming ignorance.

The 5 lamps symbolize:
  • Panch Parameshthi (five great personalities: Arihant, Siddha, Ächärya, Upädhyäy, Sädhu)
  • Five types of jnän (knowledge: Mati-jnän, Shrut-jnän, Avadhi-jnän, Manah-paryav jnän, Keval-jnän)
  • Panch Mahävrat (five great vows: Non-Violence, Non-stealing, Truthfulness, Celibacy, Non-possession)

tabData.tagHTML: The Auspicious Lamp

The Mangal Deevo is a lamp with one oil-soaked wick, lit and waved in a circle right after Ärati. When it's lit, the face of the Jina lights up. We hope this lights up our hearts with truth and compassion. The single lamp also symbolizes Keval-jnän (infinite knowledge) and a Siddha (liberated soul).

tabData.title: The Eight Auspicious Objects
tabData.description: These eight unique objects are believed to bring good luck and happiness. They are often depicted with rice grains in front of Tirthankar’s idol, or engraved on wood/metal in temples, or hung over home thresholds.

items.content: The Swastik symbolizes four destinies: human beings, heavenly beings, hellish beings, and remainder of living beings (Tiryancha). (See Swastik Symbol tab for more details)
Depicted on a Jina’s chest, the Shrivatsa is a mark that speaks to the highest knowledge manifested from the heart of the Jina. It symbolizes the endless cycle of rebirth.
This is a big Swastik with nine corners. It indicates treasures of nine kinds, including material, physical, mental, and spiritual wealth.
Vardhamän means to increase. The Vardhamänak symbolizes increase in wealth, health, and, most importantly, spiritual progress.
The Kalash symbolizes all spiritual wealth, as well as a completeness of knowledge. Its mouth represents eternity, its throat represents losing old ways, and its base represents adopting new ways.
Also called a Simhäsan, the Bhadrasan is a throne. It is considered auspicious since it is sanctified by the feet of the Jina.
It symbolizes beings rescued from the ocean of misery, which stems from an earthly existence.
It symbolizes the true self – one's soul.

tabData.tagHTML: The Pillar of Pride

The Mäna-sthambha is a pillar usually found in front of Digambar temples. It helps us overcome pride. The story goes that Indrabhuti Gautam, who was very proud of his knowledge, lost all his pride just by seeing this pillar in front of Bhagawän Mahävir's Samavasaran (assembly hall).
